content: Decide where and how you want to live. How deep into the woods do you want to live? Think both geographically and philosophically. If you don't mind a short drive outside of the urban sprawl, you can live surrounded by woods and still have some of the conveniences of the city. You can usually have electricity run to your home and get hooked up to a rural water main. A brief commute and you can be at work, making the kind of money that would be hard for some to walk away from. Or were you thinking of something a little more intense? This lifestyle still ties one down to the system; however, it offers most people enough of a reprieve to be happy. Others can't find happiness just on the other side of the suburbs. They desire to be further removed from the rat race, and live deeper in the woods. As far as North America goes, great places to get your Thoreau on are British Columbia, the Pacific Northwest of the States, and vast expanses like Montana. Just make sure you're near water! Where you choose all depends on what you have in mind and what kind of weather you're willing to, well, weather. If you want to live deeper in the woods, plan out your utilities. So many of us take for granted modern conveniences. We turn on our faucet and out comes water. Want light? Flip a switch. Want heat? Just turn up the thermostat. We forget how easy we have it. Although paying for them monthly can be challenging, having a well drilled and installing solar panels and wind turbines require a substantial initial investment that most people simply can't afford. Heating with wood is an option, but cutting wood is back breaking, time consuming work, that would probably have most wishing for the days they paid for their heat. So plan out your utilities! It will help you decide where and how you want to live. Do you want to live in a cabin in the mountains or do you want to pitch your own tent and live by the light of an oil lamp? Is the location you have in mind good year around or is it plain freezing in the winter? What about rainfall and other possibly dangerous hazards? Just how much work do you want to be doing? Know the laws. Most areas that you may want to live in are already owned (privately or publicly). If you want to be legal about it, you'll need to buy some land. However, there are seasonal camping passes you can obtain in most states that can also give you a taste of this lifestyle. Then there's squatting -- but that can get you in pretty big trouble. Know the laws of your area and the consequences for your actions before you do anything you may regret. Consider being in some type of community. If you want to truly live deeper in the woods you really need a community. Not just for your sanity, but to make it feasible. Pooling money is the only way most people can afford the high initial start up costs of living as far from the rat race as possible. Land purchase, construction materials, solar panels, and having a well drilled, are all very expensive. Even if you plan on living in a sleeping bag and foraging for nuts, a community will help you stay sane -- even if it's just one or two other people! Want to find some communities that are already doing this? Three Rivers Recreation Area near Bend, Oregon; Breitenbush near Salem, Oregon; Dancing Rabbit in Missouri; Twin Oaks in Virginia; Earthhaven in North Carolina; Greater World Community near Taos, New Mexico; and Arcosanti Ecovillage in Arizona are all established off-the-grid communities. Don’t attempt a move to the woods alone. Even if you did miraculously survive, it would not be the kind of existence anyone could stand for very long. We need human interaction to keep from going crazy. Isolation is the ultimate punishment, reserved for our worst prisoners, and it almost inevitably drives them to lunacy. There are stories of hermit mountain men in Alaska who would spend weeks traveling to another's cabin and sometimes just sit, not saying anything for a whole day, forgetting how to converse, but still craving being in the company of another human being. Unless you want to be a hermit , of course. Don't burn your bridges. It's not a good idea, when you're on this woods-living kick, to call up your mom/boss and tell them a thing or two about where they can stick it and then tell them you're going to go live in the woods. You may need them when a bear's attacked you or all the rice is gone. Whatever connections you're thinking about leaving behind, do it tactfully. You may need them later. Let everyone that you care about, that cares about you, know of your plan. Explain your reasons as logically as possible. Most of them will probably be naysayers, most of them probably won't understand, and that's fine. They don't need to. But they do deserve the privilege of knowing and not worrying about you. Try it temporarily first. Capitalism has a tendency to stick in the craw of some of us and have us swearing that, "We'd be better off living in the woods!" Sure, society has gotten to you, the materialism of every inch of this world is heartbreaking, but just try it temporarily at first. Seriously. You wouldn't buy a house without looking at it first, right? You wouldn't get married to a stranger. You wouldn't buy a car without test-driving it, yeah? So try it temporarily. There's always the possibility that you'll hate it. Or that a month will be enough! Remember those seasonal camping passes we mentioned? Those are perfect for this. Only instead of de-winterizing the RV, go out there with your tent, your sleeping bag, a jar of peanut butter, and a fishing net. How long can you last? How long can your happiness last? If you love it, come back, stock up for the year, and go back. No harm, no foul. Use the summer and fall to your advantage. You know Napoleon attacked Russia in winter and the Russians were all, "Good luck with that, buddy?" Don't be Napoleon. When the weather is nice, stock up. Gather your food (whether it's canned goods or nuts you're burying for winter), gather your firewood, gather your blankets and your snow gear, and ready yourself for the harsher months. When winter does roll around, you can stay in your tent sipping tea from pine needles and reading Emerson. Also use the summer and fall to practice your skills. You'll need to get decent at setting traps, sharpening knives, hunting and gathering, preserving meat, recognizing plants, first-aid, fire building, and fishing (fly, net, and regular), just to get you started. Gather supplies . If you're in this for the long haul, there will be times when Mother Nature isn't so nice to you. There will probably be heavy rainfall (or drought), snow, wind, fires, and ice to combat. Be sure you're prepared for anything and everything! Here's a quick list of things you'll need to get you started: Heavy layers, boots, long underwear, gloves, hats, scarves Multiple tents and blankets (including a space blanket (extremely reflective Mylar -- good for battling the elements and hypothermia)) Matches, a fire steel (a metal match) tinder and flint, making fire easier to create in cold and wet times Flashlight, lantern, extra batteries, radio, whistle First-aid kit, medicines, antiseptic, water-purifying tablets Tools, rope, knives, cord, waterproof canisters Get real. This is no joke. Living in the woods is a dangerous situation and many haven't made it out alive. If you plan on doing it for an extended amount of time, what amenities of civilization to you want to hold onto? It's not selling out to have a cup to drink out of, you know. Consider the following: Camping stove Dry goods, canned or otherwise (carbs are a good idea) Cups, silverware, plates, pots, pans Radio, walkie-talkies Books and other entertainment Read up on the art of forestry. If you dropped most people into the woods, they'd die in a matter of days. Days might even be generous. But if you read up on what you can use to your advantage when it comes to the local flora and fauna (Birch wood is good for bedding and shelter!), life will be a lot more interesting and a lot easier. And you won't end up munching on those poisonous berries for dinner. If you think the corporate world is cruel, the woods can be just as terrifying, if not more. There are plants that will make you bust out in hives, there are plants that are only poisonous when raw, there are plants with delicious berries but leaves that give you diarrhea, and that's not even mentioning the trees, soil, and animals. So get to book learning! "Bushcraft - Outdoor Skills and Wilderness Survival" by Mors Kochanski is a good place to start. There's also "How to Live in the Woods" by Homer Halsted and the entire thing is available online! [1] Consider arming yourself. With the right licensure, carrying a gun isn't a terrible idea. It could get you out of a sticky situation or two -- but do know that it could also get you into one, too. And did you plan on doing any hunting? Apart from that, consider investing in bear spray and other devices to ward off dangerous animals. You don't need to tote a gun to defend yourself, but you shouldn't rely on your bare hands either. You probably don't want to strap broken bottles to your knuckles and fight off wolves in the snow, you know? Learn about the area. If you do yourself one favor, it'll be learning about your area. You want to live near water, you want to live where there isn't a lot of danger (from nosy park rangers or grizzlies, whichever), and you want to know what exactly you have at your disposal. Sure, you could figure it out as you go, but since you have the liberty of picking where you end up, might as well pick the best place. Be sure to equip yourself with a map and compass. You will get lost. You will wonder where that one cave was. You may even decide you've had enough and decide to do the 10 mile (16 km) trek back to the highway. Who knows? Just have them for when you need them. You know how to use a compass , right? Have comfortable shelter . This part is ultimately up to you: Do you want to erect a magnificent log cabin or are you more at home in a tent ? What can you build that would take advantage of the sun, the trees, not be an eyesore, and withstand the elements? And where is the best place to make your home base? There are dozens of ways to erect a tent. Before you go about settling for a lean-to, spend a little bit more time on wikiHow. There's a plethora of camping articles you've yet to use to your advantage. Master the survival techniques. You're not just camping for a week, spending most of it floating down a river drinking Mike's Hard. You need some serious skills because this is your life 24/7. Here's a very non-exhaustive list of articles you should get to reading! You need to eat, stay warm, and be hygienic above all else, but the entire list is useful. How to Build a Fire How to Purify Water How to Create a Tripwire Trap How to Make a Snare Trap How to Make a Day Survival Kit How to Fish How to Hunt How to Take a Bath in a Sink, Bucket, or River How to Make and Use a Solar Oven Stay hygienic. When it comes to pooping in the woods (we're just gonna put it out there because you know we're all thinking it), you basically have two options: going about your business wherever and however you like or developing some long-term system. Did you know there's such a thing as a composting toilet where you can use waste to fertilize the ground? If you're there for a while, might as well make the world a better place for it! While you can go for the traditional ditch latrine, there's also the option of a regular camping toilet . Heck, with all your free time, you could develop a brand new system, too. And then there's bathing. Hopefully there's a river nearby, right? Aside from having drinking water, it's also good so your own stench doesn't drive you batty. But if for some terrible reason that's not an option, you can make a sweath bath . It's kinda like an outdoors sauna. It'll probably be a trend for city-dwellers in a few years! Consider living near something urban. While you may consider having a reprieve from the wilderness life defeating the purpose, it can come in very handy to live ten miles away from a gas station. If you're dying, just really need a real toilet, or would kill the next person you see for a package of beef jerky, it can be a true Godsend. Or if you live semi-near a town, you can go in once every few months for a few staples. There's no harm in it, Your eco-footprint is already marginal compared to the rest of us! If this is something that intrigues you, you may need a form of transportation. A bicycle makes the most sense, though a motorcycle or moped may also be feasible. Just know that it's one more thing you must know how to maintain. If you do go down this route, familiarize yourself with the mechanics of your vehicle. You should be its master -- not the other way around. Consider upgrading. Since you plan on being here for a while, why not upgrade? Go off the grid and provide yourself your own sustainable energy and way of living. It'll take some money, but do think about installing solar panels in your home (or utilizing wind energy), drilling a well and starting a septic system, using a generator, starting composting , and heck, starting farming ! This is what those communities we mentioned before are doing, but you can definitely do it on your own. You're already going near-green; why not reduce your eco-footprint entirely by providing yourself everything -- literally everything -- you need? Not like you have a 9-to-5 to blame, right? Someone's gotta make up for the rest of us. And imagine how gratifying it would feel to harness your own energy and make all your own food. Holy cow. Have a craft. You'll probably want something to do with your time, right? Many off-the-gridders make soaps and lotions, make cloth, blankets, etc. from animal hides, wood carve, make teas and syrups, and master other hobbies that utilize nature. You could even make a little side money, if that interests you. Whether it's for a profit or just for you, having an art is a very good, life-affirming thing. Always do what's best for you. Living in the woods is an enormous feat. Even doing it for days is nothing to shake a stick at. It also can cause a person to get inside their own head and drive themselves crazy. You may come to realize that you don't know who you are, what this thing called life is all about, or what really to do with yourself. It might be infinitely more disturbing than you could ever imagine. Or it could be so freeing you don't know why you didn't do it sooner. Either way, always keep your mental health in mind. People will question your sanity, you may even question your sanity, but if you're happy, continue on. Stay safe, warm, healthy, and strive to live the life you dream of. Whatever it may be.
title_html: How to Live in the Woods

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Live-in-the-Woods">How to Live in the Woods</a></h1>
<div class="" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="staff_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		wikiHow Staff</a><span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a class="expert_coauthor_link ss_review" href="#article_info_section">Reader-Approved</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Forming_a_Plan_sub" id="">Forming a Plan</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Being_Adequately_Prepared_sub" id="">Being Adequately Prepared</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Living_in_the_Woods_--_Not_Just_Surviving_sub" id="">Living in the Woods -- Not Just Surviving
</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by our trained team of editors and researchers who validated it for accuracy and comprehensiveness. wikiHow's <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers#wikihow%20content%20team%20managers">Content Management Team</a> carefully monitors the work from our editorial staff to ensure that each article meets our high standards.<br/><br/>wikiHow marks an article as reader-approved once it receives enough positive feedback. This article has over 181,415 views and 87% of readers who voted found it helpful, earning it our reader-approved status.
		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>
</div>
</div>
<p>Living in the woods, surrounded by nature, is a fantasy of many city dwellers. Running the rat race day after day, dealing with traffic, crime, and pollution -- it’s easy to romantically imagine a life more serene. Through proper planning and sacrifice, living in the woods can be an attainable dream. And soon an attainable reality.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Forming_a_Plan_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Forming_a_Plan">Forming a Plan</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 01" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg" height="546" id="img_33d66c066d" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_33d66c066d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 01" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-01.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Decide where and how you want to live.</b> How deep into the woods do you want to live? Think both geographically and philosophically. If you don't mind a short drive outside of the urban sprawl, you can live surrounded by woods and still have some of the conveniences of the city. You can usually have electricity run to your home and get hooked up to a rural water main. A brief commute and you can be at work, making the kind of money that would be hard for some to walk away from. Or were you thinking of something a little more intense?

<ul>
<li>This lifestyle still ties one down to the system; however, it offers most people enough of a reprieve to be happy. Others can't find happiness just on the other side of the suburbs. They desire to be further removed from the rat race, and live deeper in the woods.</li>
<li>As far as North America goes, great places to get your Thoreau on are British Columbia, the Pacific Northwest of the States, and vast expanses like Montana. Just make sure you're near water! Where you choose all depends on what you have in mind and what kind of weather you're willing to, well, weather.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 02" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg" height="546" id="img_e210402f02" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e210402f02')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 02" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-02.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">If you want to live deeper in the woods, plan out your utilities.</b> So many of us take for granted modern conveniences. We turn on our faucet and out comes water. Want light? Flip a switch. Want heat? Just turn up the thermostat. We forget how easy we have it. Although paying for them monthly can be challenging, having a well drilled and installing solar panels and wind turbines require a substantial initial investment that most people simply can't afford. Heating with wood is an option, but cutting wood is back breaking, time consuming work, that would probably have most wishing for the days they paid for their heat. So plan out your utilities! It will help you decide where and how you want to live.

<ul>
<li>Do you want to live in a cabin in the mountains or do you want to pitch your own tent and live by the light of an oil lamp? Is the location you have in mind good year around or is it plain freezing in the winter? What about rainfall and other possibly dangerous hazards? Just how much work do you want to be doing?</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 03" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg" height="546" id="img_9ddecc9b64" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9ddecc9b64')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 03" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-03.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know the laws.</b> Most areas that you may want to live in are already owned (privately or publicly). If you want to be legal about it, you'll need to buy some land. However, there are seasonal camping passes you can obtain in most states that can also give you a taste of this lifestyle. Then there's squatting -- but that can get you in pretty big trouble. Know the laws of your area and the consequences for your actions before you do anything you may regret.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 04" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg" height="546" id="img_f300648cc3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f300648cc3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 04" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-04.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider being in some type of community.</b> If you want to truly live deeper in the woods you really need a community. Not just for your sanity, but to make it feasible. Pooling money is the only way most people can afford the high initial start up costs of living as far from the rat race as possible. Land purchase, construction materials, solar panels, and having a well drilled, are all very expensive. Even if you plan on living in a sleeping bag and foraging for nuts, a community will help you stay sane -- even if it's just one or two other people!

<ul>
<li>Want to find some communities that are already doing this? Three Rivers Recreation Area near Bend, Oregon; Breitenbush near Salem, Oregon; Dancing Rabbit in Missouri; Twin Oaks in Virginia; Earthhaven in North Carolina; Greater World Community near Taos, New Mexico; and Arcosanti Ecovillage in Arizona are all established off-the-grid communities.
<ul>
<li>Don’t attempt a move to the woods alone. Even if you did miraculously survive, it would not be the kind of existence anyone could stand for very long. We need human interaction to keep from going crazy. Isolation is the ultimate punishment, reserved for our worst prisoners, and it almost inevitably drives them to lunacy. There are stories of hermit mountain men in Alaska who would spend weeks traveling to another's cabin and sometimes just sit, not saying anything for a whole day, forgetting how to converse, but still craving being in the company of another human being. Unless you want to <a href="/Be-a-Hermit" title="Be a Hermit">be a hermit</a>, of course.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 05" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg" height="546" id="img_6014de4ea7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6014de4ea7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 05" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-05.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't burn your bridges.</b> It's not a good idea, when you're on this woods-living kick, to call up your mom/boss and tell them a thing or two about where they can stick it and then tell them you're going to go live in the woods. You may need them when a bear's attacked you or all the rice is gone. Whatever connections you're thinking about leaving behind, do it tactfully. You may need them later.

<ul>
<li>Let everyone that you care about, that cares about you, know of your plan. Explain your reasons as logically as possible. Most of them will probably be naysayers, most of them probably won't understand, and that's fine. They don't need to. But they do deserve the privilege of knowing and not worrying about you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Being_Adequately_Prepared_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Being_Adequately_Prepared">Being Adequately Prepared</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 06" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg" height="546" id="img_9a62393f5c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9a62393f5c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 06" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-06.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Try it temporarily first.</b> Capitalism has a tendency to stick in the craw of some of us and have us swearing that, "We'd be better off living in the woods!" Sure, society has gotten to you, the materialism of every inch of this world is heartbreaking, but just try it temporarily at first. Seriously. You wouldn't buy a house without looking at it first, right? You wouldn't get married to a stranger. You wouldn't buy a car without test-driving it, yeah? So try it temporarily. There's always the possibility that you'll hate it. Or that a month will be enough!

<ul>
<li>Remember those seasonal camping passes we mentioned? Those are perfect for this. Only instead of de-winterizing the RV, go out there with your tent, your sleeping bag, a jar of peanut butter, and a fishing net. How long can you last? How long can your happiness last? If you love it, come back, stock up for the year, and go back. No harm, no foul.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 07" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg" height="546" id="img_f81f33926a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f81f33926a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 07" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-07.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use the summer and fall to your advantage.</b> You know Napoleon attacked Russia in winter and the Russians were all, "Good luck with that, buddy?" Don't be Napoleon. When the weather is nice, stock up. Gather your food (whether it's canned goods or nuts you're burying for winter), gather your firewood, gather your blankets and your snow gear, and ready yourself for the harsher months. When winter does roll around, you can stay in your tent sipping tea from pine needles and reading Emerson.

<ul>
<li>Also use the summer and fall to practice your skills. You'll need to get decent at setting traps, sharpening knives, hunting and gathering, preserving meat, recognizing plants, first-aid, fire building, and fishing (fly, net, and regular), just to get you started.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 08" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg" height="546" id="img_30aedaae10" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_30aedaae10')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 08" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-08.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Pack-an-Emergency-Case-for-a-Camping-Trip" title="Pack an Emergency Case for a Camping Trip">Gather supplies</a>.</b> If you're in this for the long haul, there will be times when Mother Nature isn't so nice to you. There will probably be heavy rainfall (or drought), snow, wind, fires, and ice to combat. Be sure you're prepared for anything and everything! Here's a quick list of things you'll need to get you started:

<ul>
<li>Heavy layers, boots, long underwear, gloves, hats, scarves</li>
<li>Multiple tents and blankets (including a space blanket (extremely reflective Mylar -- good for battling the elements and hypothermia))</li>
<li>Matches, a fire steel (a metal match) tinder and flint, making fire easier to create in cold and wet times</li>
<li>Flashlight, lantern, extra batteries, radio, whistle</li>
<li>First-aid kit, medicines, antiseptic, water-purifying tablets</li>
<li>Tools, rope, knives, cord, waterproof canisters</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 09" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg" height="546" id="img_b63c0179fa" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b63c0179fa')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 09" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-09.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get real.</b> This is no joke. Living in the woods is a dangerous situation and many haven't made it out alive. If you plan on doing it for an extended amount of time, what amenities of civilization to you want to hold onto? It's not selling out to have a cup to drink out of, you know. Consider the following:

<ul>
<li>Camping stove</li>
<li>Dry goods, canned or otherwise (carbs are a good idea)</li>
<li>Cups, silverware, plates, pots, pans</li>
<li>Radio, walkie-talkies</li>
<li>Books and other entertainment</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_98b567feea" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_98b567feea')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Read up on the art of forestry.</b> If you dropped most people into the woods, they'd die in a matter of days. Days might even be generous. But if you read up on what you can use to your advantage when it comes to the local flora and fauna (Birch wood is good for bedding <i>and</i> shelter!), life will be a lot more interesting and a lot easier. And you won't end up munching on those poisonous berries for dinner.

<ul>
<li>If you think the corporate world is cruel, the woods can be just as terrifying, if not more. There are plants that will make you bust out in hives, there are plants that are only poisonous when raw, there are plants with delicious berries but leaves that give you diarrhea, and that's not even mentioning the trees, soil, and animals. So get to book learning!</li>
<li>"Bushcraft - Outdoor Skills and Wilderness Survival" by Mors Kochanski is a good place to start. There's also "How to Live in the Woods" by Homer Halsted and the entire thing is available online!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_7ebf90796a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7ebf90796a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider arming yourself.</b> With the right licensure, carrying a gun isn't a terrible idea. It could get you out of a sticky situation or two -- but do know that it could also get you <i>into</i> one, too. And did you plan on doing any hunting?

<ul>
<li>Apart from that, consider investing in bear spray and other devices to ward off dangerous animals. You don't need to tote a gun to defend yourself, but you shouldn't rely on your bare hands either. You probably don't want to strap broken bottles to your knuckles and fight off wolves in the snow, you know?</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_08dcdbccf2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_08dcdbccf2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Learn about the area.</b> If you do yourself one favor, it'll be learning about your area. You want to live near water, you want to live where there isn't a lot of danger (from nosy park rangers or grizzlies, whichever), and you want to know what exactly you have at your disposal. Sure, you could figure it out as you go, but since you have the liberty of <i>picking</i> where you end up, might as well pick the best place.

<ul>
<li>Be sure to equip yourself with a map and compass. You will get lost. You will wonder where that one cave was. You may even decide you've had enough and decide to do the 10 mile (16 km) trek back to the highway. Who knows? Just have them for when you need them. You know <a href="/Use-a-Compass" title="Use a Compass">how to use a compass</a>, right?</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,4805470868" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Living_in_the_Woods_--_Not_Just_Surviving_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Living_in_the_Woods_--_Not_Just_Surviving">Living in the Woods -- <a href="/Survive-in-the-Woods" title="Survive in the Woods">Not Just Surviving</a>
</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_b032370d22" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b032370d22')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Build-a-Survival-Shelter-in-a-Wooded-Area" title="Build a Survival Shelter in a Wooded Area">Have comfortable shelter</a>.</b> This part is ultimately up to you: Do you want to <a href="/Build-a-Log-House" title="Build a Log House">erect a magnificent log cabin</a> or are you more at home <a href="/Assemble-a-Tent" title="Assemble a Tent">in a tent</a>? What can you build that would take advantage of the sun, the trees, not be an eyesore, and withstand the elements? And where is the best place to make your home base?

<ul>
<li>There are dozens of ways to erect a tent. Before you go about settling for a lean-to, spend a little bit more time on wikiHow. There's a plethora of <a class="external text" href="http://www.wikihow.com/Category:Camping" rel="nofollow">camping articles</a> you've yet to use to your advantage.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_84b9b13ffc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_84b9b13ffc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Master the survival techniques.</b> You're not just camping for a week, spending most of it floating down a river drinking Mike's Hard. You need some serious skills because this is your life 24/7. Here's a very non-exhaustive list of articles you should get to reading! You need to eat, stay warm, and be hygienic above all else, but the entire list is useful.

<ul>
<li><a href="/Build-a-Fire" title="Build a Fire">How to Build a Fire</a></li>
<li><a href="/Purify-Water" title="Purify Water">How to Purify Water</a></li>
<li>How to Create a Tripwire Trap</li>
<li><a href="/Make-a-Snare-Trap" title="Make a Snare Trap">How to Make a Snare Trap</a></li>
<li>How to Make a Day Survival Kit</li>
<li><a href="/Fish" title="Fish">How to Fish</a></li>
<li><a href="/Hunt" title="Hunt">How to Hunt</a></li>
<li>How to Take a Bath in a Sink, Bucket, or River</li>
<li><a href="/Make-and-Use-a-Solar-Oven" title="Make and Use a Solar Oven">How to Make and Use a Solar Oven</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_ed6ec9f815" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ed6ec9f815')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stay hygienic.</b> When it comes to <a href="/Defecate-Outdoors" title="Defecate Outdoors">pooping in the woods</a> (we're just gonna put it out there because you know we're all thinking it), you basically have two options: going about your business wherever and however you like or developing some long-term system. Did you know there's such a thing as a composting toilet where you can use waste to fertilize the ground? If you're there for a while, might as well make the world a better place for it!

<ul>
<li>While you can go for the traditional ditch latrine, there's also the option of a regular <a href="/Make-a-Camping-Toilet" title="Make a Camping Toilet">camping toilet</a>. Heck, with all your free time, you could develop a brand new system, too.</li>
<li>And then there's bathing. Hopefully there's a river nearby, right? Aside from having drinking water, it's also good so your own stench doesn't drive you batty. But if for some terrible reason that's not an option, you can <a href="/Make-a-Sweat-Bath-in-the-Wilderness" title="Make a Sweat Bath in the Wilderness">make a sweath bath</a>. It's kinda like an outdoors sauna. It'll probably be a trend for city-dwellers in a few years!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_47711813a5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_47711813a5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider living near something urban.</b> While you may consider having a reprieve from the wilderness life defeating the purpose, it can come in very handy to live ten miles away from a gas station. If you're dying, just really need a real toilet, or would kill the next person you see for a package of beef jerky, it can be a true Godsend. Or if you live semi-near a town, you can go in once every few months for a few staples. There's no harm in it, Your eco-footprint is already marginal compared to the rest of us!

<ul>
<li>If this is something that intrigues you, you may need a form of transportation. A bicycle makes the most sense, though a motorcycle or moped may also be feasible. Just know that it's one more thing you must know how to maintain. If you do go down this route, familiarize yourself with the mechanics of your vehicle. You should be its master -- not the other way around.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_63591c8f4d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_63591c8f4d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider upgrading.</b> Since you plan on being here for a while, why not upgrade? Go <a href="/Live-off-the-Grid" title="Live off the Grid">off the grid</a> and provide yourself your own sustainable energy and way of living. It'll take some money, but do think about installing solar panels in your home (or utilizing wind energy), drilling a well and starting a septic system, using a generator, <a href="/Compost" title="Compost">starting composting</a>, and heck, <a href="/Start-a-Farm" title="Start a Farm">starting farming</a>!

<ul>
<li>This is what those communities we mentioned before are doing, but you can definitely do it on your own. You're already going near-green; why not reduce your eco-footprint entirely by providing yourself everything -- literally <i>everything</i> -- you need? Not like you have a 9-to-5 to blame, right? Someone's gotta make up for the rest of us. And imagine how gratifying it would feel to harness your own energy and make all your own food. Holy cow.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_8d8dbdd7c3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8d8dbdd7c3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f0/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Have a craft.</b> You'll probably want something to do with your time, right? Many off-the-gridders make soaps and lotions, make cloth, blankets, etc. from animal hides, wood carve, make teas and syrups, and master other hobbies that utilize nature. You could even make a little side money, if that interests you. Whether it's for a profit or just for you, having an art is a very good, life-affirming thing.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1517667" href="#/Image:Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg" height="546" id="img_e21166ced8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e21166ced8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Live in the Woods Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg/aid1517667-v4-728px-Live-in-the-Woods-Step-19.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Always do what's best for you.</b> Living in the woods is an enormous feat. Even doing it for days is nothing to shake a stick at. It also can cause a person to get inside their own head and drive themselves crazy. You may come to realize that you don't know who you are, what this thing called life is all about, or what really to do with yourself. It might be infinitely more disturbing than you could ever imagine. Or it could be so freeing you don't know why you didn't do it sooner.

<ul>
<li>Either way, always keep your mental health in mind. People will question your sanity, you may even question your sanity, but if you're happy, continue on. Stay safe, warm, healthy, and strive to live the life you dream of. Whatever it may be.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="1517667" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="220304" data-caid="221177" data-cqid="220321" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1365067" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="18">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How do I train animals to serve me?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It would be quite difficult to domesticate feral animals to do your bidding. However, if you put out food routinely for the animals sharing the woods with you and pose them no threat, they will at least view you as an ally over time, and visit routinely.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>18</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="405401" data-caid="406274" data-cqid="405418" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2303906" data-submitter_id="3911021" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="5">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Why do most people not make it back alive, living in the woods?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-Hb3LeidhHlc/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAAG0/DMRTAu6yU3w/s96-c/photo.jpg)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Nicholas-Newman">Nicholas Newman</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">They are not prepared in the basic needs of survival. You need water most importantly, shelter to keep you from the elements, and a means of obtaining food, which should include something to generate a fire.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>5</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="259907" data-caid="260780" data-cqid="259924" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1433167" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="3" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Is it legal to live in an area that no one owns?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Technically, however, there are not many places left that no one owns. Just because you don't know who owns it doesn't mean it's not owned.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="549408" data-caid="550281" data-cqid="549425" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2261493" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="1">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Am I allowed to live in a forest that isn't public, but also isn't really protected?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Legally, no; someone owns the property, and you could be reported for trespassing. However, if by "isn't really protected" you mean that it's not monitored, you could probably get away with it if you're discreet, quiet, stay concealed, and leave little indication of your presence. </div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="568279" data-caid="569152" data-cqid="568296" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2237003" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">

<div id="qa_box"></div>
<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>The most important thing is planning. The considerations are so many they could fill an encyclopedia. Planning the land purchase, legal documents to file, transportation, construction, water, energy, food, and yes, even a revenue stream. You might not need a traditional job, but you will still need at least some money. Property taxes will still need to be paid, and some bills and services paid for in cash. Unfortunately, no one lives completely free from the all mighty dollar anymore. The better you plan, the better your chances of success.</li>
<li>Please watch a documentary called "The Garbage Warrior," to see how effectively a group of people can pool their resources, and labor, to build a Utopian society that is totally 'off the grid'. The man behind the community is Michael Reynolds,a radically innovative architect who utilizes renewable energy, and builds with recyclable materials, creating what he calls Earth Ships. They are totally self sustained, and not hooked up to any gas, electric, water or sewer lines. It is truly amazing!</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Don't just take a knife and box of matches and get dropped off in some isolated wilderness because you’ve watched all the Bear Grylls episodes and you think you are an expert. You will most likely die.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

    "headline": "Live in the Woods",
    "name": "Live in the Woods",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {

        "@type": "ImageObject",

        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {

            "height": 60
